# Homogeneous Structures

**Recall:** We have seen that DLO is $\omega$-categorical, meaning up to isomorphism there is only one countable model. Since there are no finite models, by Vaught's test, DLO is complete.

**Question:** Are there other examples like this?

::: {.callout-note icon=false}
## Definition

Let $\mathcal{L}$ be a language and $\mathcal{M}$ be an $\mathcal{L}$-structure. We say $\mathcal{M}$ is *(ultra) homogeneous* if any isomorphism between finitely generated substructures of $\mathcal{M}$ extends to an automorphism of $\mathcal{M}$.

For $A \subseteq M$, we denote by $\langle A \rangle^{\mathcal{M}}$ the smallest substructure of $\mathcal{M}$ whose domain contains $A$.

We say $\mathcal{M} \supseteq \mathcal{N}$ is finitely generated if $\mathcal{N} = \langle A \rangle^{\mathcal{M}}$ for some finite $A \subseteq M$.
:::

::: {.callout-tip icon=false}
## Example

Let $\mathcal{L} = \{<\}$ and $\mathcal{M} = (\mathbb{Q}, <)$. Then finitely generated is equivalent to having a finite substructure.
:::

## Back-and-Forth and Homogeneity

In the back-and-forth proof of $\omega$-categoricity of DLO, we used a homogeneity property, similarly for the proof that $(\mathbb{Q}, <) \cong (\mathbb{R}, <)$.

::: {.callout-note icon=false}
## Definition

The *age* of $\mathcal{M}$, denoted $\mathrm{age}(\mathcal{M})$, is the class of all finitely generated $\mathcal{L}$-structures isomorphic to a substructure of $\mathcal{M}$.
:::

::: {.callout-tip icon=false}
## Example

$\mathrm{age}(\mathbb{Q}, <)$ is the class of all finite linear orders.
:::

::: {.callout-important icon=false}
## Lemma

Any two countable homogeneous structures with the same age are isomorphic.
:::

::: {.callout-warning icon=false collapse=true}
## Proof sketch

Let $\mathcal{A} \subseteq \mathcal{M}$ and $\mathcal{B} \subseteq \mathcal{N}$ be finitely generated, and let $\pi: \mathcal{A} \to \mathcal{B}$ be an isomorphism.

Let $a \in M \setminus A$. We need to show that $\pi$ can be extended to an isomorphism $\mathcal{A} \cup \{a\} \to \mathcal{B}'$.

This suffices, since we can then use the back-and-forth argument.

Suppose $\mathcal{A} = \langle E \rangle^{\mathcal{M}}$ and $\mathcal{B} = \langle F \rangle^{\mathcal{N}}$.

Then $\widetilde{\pi}: E \leftrightarrow F$ extends uniquely to $\pi$.

Let $\mathcal{A}' = \langle E \cup \{a\} \rangle^{\mathcal{M}} \subseteq \mathcal{M}$.

Since $\mathcal{M}$ and $\mathcal{N}$ have the same age, there exists $\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathcal{N}$ finitely generated such that $\mathcal{A}' \cong \mathcal{C}$ via some isomorphism $g$.

Note that $\mathcal{A}' \cong \mathcal{C}$ via $g$. The map $g$ is uniquely determined by its values on $E \cup \{a\}$.

The restriction $g|_E$ induces an isomorphism $\langle E \rangle^{\mathcal{M}} \xrightarrow{\cong} \langle g(E) \rangle^{\mathcal{N}}$.

Therefore, $\pi \circ (g|_E)^{-1}$ is an isomorphism $\mathcal{B} \xrightarrow{\cong} \langle g(E) \rangle^{\mathcal{N}}$.

Call this map $\tau$. Note that $\langle g(E) \rangle^{\mathcal{N}}$ is a finitely generated subset of $\mathcal{N}$.

Since $\mathcal{N}$ is homogeneous, $\tau$ extends to an automorphism $\overline{\tau}: \mathcal{N} \to \mathcal{N}$.

This yields an isomorphism $\mathcal{A}' \to \mathcal{B} \cup \{\overline{\tau}(g(a))\}$.
:::

**Question:** What do ages of homogeneous structures look like?

\section*{Homogeneous Structures}

\textbf{Recall:} We have seen that DLO is $\omega$-categorical, meaning up to isomorphism there is only one countable model. Since there are no finite models, by Vaught's test, DLO is complete.

\textbf{Question:} Are there other examples like this?

\begin{definition}
Let $\mathcal{L}$ be a language and $\mathcal{M}$ be an $\mathcal{L}$-structure. We say $\mathcal{M}$ is \emph{(ultra) homogeneous} if any isomorphism between finitely generated substructures of $\mathcal{M}$ extends to an automorphism of $\mathcal{M}$.

For $A \subseteq M$, we denote by $\langle A \rangle^{\mathcal{M}}$ the smallest substructure of $\mathcal{M}$ whose domain contains $A$.

We say $\mathcal{M} \supseteq \mathcal{N}$ is finitely generated if $\mathcal{N} = \langle A \rangle^{\mathcal{M}}$ for some finite $A \subseteq M$.
\end{definition}

\begin{example}
Let $\mathcal{L} = \{<\}$ and $\mathcal{M} = (\mathbb{Q}, <)$. Then finitely generated is equivalent to having a finite substructure.
\end{example}

\section*{Back-and-Forth and Homogeneity}

In the back-and-forth proof of $\omega$-categoricity of DLO, we used a homogeneity property, similarly for the proof that $(\mathbb{Q}, <) \cong (\mathbb{R}, <)$.

\begin{definition}
The \emph{age} of $\mathcal{M}$, denoted $\mathrm{age}(\mathcal{M})$, is the class of all finitely generated $\mathcal{L}$-structures isomorphic to a substructure of $\mathcal{M}$.
\end{definition}

\begin{example}
$\mathrm{age}(\mathbb{Q}, <)$ is the class of all finite linear orders.
\end{example}

\begin{lemma}
Any two countable homogeneous structures with the same age are isomorphic.
\end{lemma}

\begin{proof}[Proof sketch]
Let $\mathcal{A} \subseteq \mathcal{M}$ and $\mathcal{B} \subseteq \mathcal{N}$ be finitely generated, and let $\pi: \mathcal{A} \to \mathcal{B}$ be an isomorphism.

Let $a \in M \setminus A$. We need to show that $\pi$ can be extended to an isomorphism $\mathcal{A} \cup \{a\} \to \mathcal{B}'$.

This suffices, since we can then use the back-and-forth argument.

Suppose $\mathcal{A} = \langle E \rangle^{\mathcal{M}}$ and $\mathcal{B} = \langle F \rangle^{\mathcal{N}}$.

Then $\widetilde{\pi}: E \leftrightarrow F$ extends uniquely to $\pi$.

Let $\mathcal{A}' = \langle E \cup \{a\} \rangle^{\mathcal{M}} \subseteq \mathcal{M}$.

Since $\mathcal{M}$ and $\mathcal{N}$ have the same age, there exists $\mathcal{C} \subseteq \mathcal{N}$ finitely generated such that $\mathcal{A}' \cong \mathcal{C}$ via some isomorphism $g$.

Note that $\mathcal{A}' \cong \mathcal{C}$ via $g$. The map $g$ is uniquely determined by its values on $E \cup \{a\}$.

The restriction $g|_E$ induces an isomorphism $\langle E \rangle^{\mathcal{M}} \xrightarrow{\cong} \langle g(E) \rangle^{\mathcal{N}}$.

Therefore, $\pi \circ (g|_E)^{-1}$ is an isomorphism $\mathcal{B} \xrightarrow{\cong} \langle g(E) \rangle^{\mathcal{N}}$.

Call this map $\tau$. Note that $\langle g(E) \rangle^{\mathcal{N}}$ is a finitely generated subset of $\mathcal{N}$.

Since $\mathcal{N}$ is homogeneous, $\tau$ extends to an automorphism $\overline{\tau}: \mathcal{N} \to \mathcal{N}$.

This yields an isomorphism $\mathcal{A}' \to \mathcal{B} \cup \{\overline{\tau}(g(a))\}$.
\end{proof}

\textbf{Question:} What do ages of homogeneous structures look like?
